title: Clark v. Aiken County Government
description: This is a workers' compensation case involving an award based on change of condition.  We affirm the Workers' Compensation Commission and circuit court's findings that Clark sustained a change of physical condition resulting in permanent and total disability.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Joseph Mark Clark, Sr., Respondent,
v.
Aiken County Government & South Carolina Property and Casualty Insurance Guaranty Association, formerly Legion Insurance Company,
Appellants.
      
    
  


Appeal from Aiken County
Â James R. Barber, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4023
Heard June 7, 2005 â€“ Filed September 12, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Mark D. Cauthen and R. Daniel Addison, both of Columbia, and David A. Wilson and Michael Allen Farry, both of Greenville, for Appellants.
Franklin D. Beattie, Jr., of Georgetown, for Respondent.
      
    
  

CURETON, A.J.:Â  This is a workersâ€™ compensation case involving an award based on change of condition.Â  The Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission found that Joseph Mark Clark, Sr. sustained a change of physical condition resulting in permanent and total disability, and the circuit court affirmed.Â  We affirm as well. 
FACTS
The parties stipulated that Clark sustained an injury on July 12, 1999 in an accident arising out of and in the course of his employment with Aiken County.Â  Clark twisted his lower back while attempting to unhook a trailer from a vehicle.Â  The parties also stipulated to an average weekly wage and compensation rate.Â Â Â  
In the original proceeding, the single commissioner found Clark reached MMI on January 20, 2000 and that he had sustained a 30% permanent partial disability as a result of the accident. He awarded benefits accordingly. Â Clark then appealed to the full commission. In his brief to the full commission, he requested, inter alia, that Dr. Martin Greenberg be designated his treating physician â€œto provide alternative medical treatment.â€Â  
While the case was pending before the full commission, Clarkâ€™s pain increased. Clark was seen by Dr. John Downey who, along with Clarkâ€™s attorney, referred him to Dr. Greenberg.Â  Dr. Greenberg recommended surgery to Clarkâ€™s back and performed the surgery on July 27, 2001. Clark did not get permission from the County for Dr. Greenberg to treat him or perform the surgery.
On August 10, 2001 the County tendered and Clark in turn accepted payment of the monetary benefits awarded by the single commissioner.
On October 9, 2001, the full commission affirmed the single commissionerâ€™s order, adopting verbatim his findings of fact and conclusions of law.Â  The full commission did not address the issue of whether Clarkâ€™s condition had changed since he reached MMI, nor did the full commission address the request in Clarkâ€™s brief that Greenberg be appointed his treating physician.Â  
The surgery successfully alleviated Clarkâ€™s pain for about four to six months.Â  Then the pain returned, although it was not as severe.Â  After examining Clark again, Dr. Greenberg determined that Clark was permanently vocationally disabled.Â  Clark has not worked since March of 2000 when the County retired him based on disability.
In January 2002, Clark filed a Form 50 claiming a substantial change of condition.Â  The single commissioner concluded that Clark sustained a worsening of his condition and had an impairment of more than 51% to his back.Â  The single commissioner further concluded that the change in physical condition occurred after August 14, 2001.Â  Accordingly, he awarded Clark benefits for total and permanent disability.Â  The single commissioner also specifically found that the treatment by Dr. Greenberg was â€œnecessary, reasonable and was an attempt to lessen [Clarkâ€™s] disability.â€ He ordered the County to pay for all past and continuing treatment provided to him. 
The County appealed to the full commission, which again affirmed, adopting the findings and conclusions of the single commissioner.Â  The circuit court also affirmed.Â  This appeal followed.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The South Carolina Administrative Procedures Act governs judicial review of a decision of an administrative agency.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 1-23-310 to 400 (Supp. 2004).Â  Section 1-23-380(A)(6) establishes the substantial evidence rule as the standard of review.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 134, 276 S.E.2d 304, 306 (1981).Â  Under this standard, a reviewing court may reverse or modify an agency decision based on errors of law, but may only reverse or modify an agencyâ€™s findings of fact if they are clearly erroneous.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(6)(d) and (e).Â  
Accordingly, a reviewing court may not substitute its judgment for that of the full commission as to the weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  Stephens v. Avins Constr. Co., 324 S.C. 334, 337, 478 S.E.2d 74, 76 (Ct. App. 1996).Â  Instead, review of issues of fact is limited to determining whether the findings are supported by substantial evidence in the record.Â  Hargrove v. Titan Textile Co., 360 S.C. 276, 289, 599 S.E.2d 604, 610-11 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œOn appeal, this court must affirm an award of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission in which the circuit court concurred if substantial evidence supports the findings.â€Â  Solomon v. W.B. Easton, Inc., 307 S.C. 518, 520, 415 S.E.2d 841, 843 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  â€œSubstantial evidence is evidence which, considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion that the administrative agency reached to justify its action.â€Â  Howell v. Pacific Columbia Mills, 291 S.C. 469, 471, 354 S.E.2d 384, 385 (1987). 
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Change of Condition
The Countyâ€™s first contention on appeal is that Clark failed to prove a change of condition entitling him to additional compensation.Â  Specifically, the County argues that because the change of condition
asserted by Clark occurred before the full commission issued its order in the initial proceeding, the change could not have occurred subsequent to the first award.Â  We disagree.Â  
Initially, Clark argues that the County failed to preserve this argument for appeal.Â  In its request for review by the full commission, the County stated as grounds for appeal, in relevant part, that the single commissioner erred in finding as a fact and concluding as a matter of law that Clark sustained a change of condition for the worse.Â  Clark argues that this assignment of error is not specific enough to preserve the argument for appeal.Â  
An issue not raised in the application for review is not preserved for the full commissionâ€™s consideration.Â  Creech v. Ducane Co., 320 S.C. 559, 564, 467 S.E.2d 114, 117 (Ct. App. 1995).Â  General exceptions that fail to specifically assign the grounds for error are insufficient to preserve an issue.Â  Bogart v. First Citizens Bank & Trust Co., 273 S.C. 179, 180, 255 S.E.2d 449, 450 (1979).Â  However, rules of appellate procedure should not be interpreted to create a trap for the unwary.Â  Elam v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 25, 602 S.E.2d 772, 780 (2004).Â  Although we find preservation tenuous at best, we nevertheless proceed to the merits.Â  
The Workersâ€™ Compensation Act provides a mechanism for reopening an award if there has been a change in condition.Â  Creech, 320 S.C. at 564, 467 S.E.2d at 117; S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-17-90 (1985).Â  The purpose of this section is to enable the full commission to change the amount of compensation, including increasing compensation when circumstances indicate a change of condition for the worse.Â  Cromer v. Newberry Cotton Mills, 201 S.C. 349, 354-55, 23 S.E.2d 19, 21 (1942).Â  Accordingly, the full commission has continuing jurisdiction over its awards for the period set forth in section 42-17-90.Â  Id.Â Â Â  
Under section 42-17-90, a change of condition must occur after the first award for a claimant to be eligible for a review of that award.Â  Cromer, 201 S.C. at 357, 23 S.E.2d at 21.Â  â€œThe issue before the Commission is sharply restricted to the question of extent of improvement or worsening of the injury on which the original award was based.â€Â  Gattis v. Murrells Inlet VFW # Â£10420, 353 S.C. 100, 109, 576 S.E.2d 191, 196 (Ct. App. 2003) (quoting Krell v. S.C. State Hwy. Depâ€™t, 237 S.C. 584, 118 S.E.2d 322 (1961)); 5 Arthur Larson, Larsonâ€™s Workersâ€™ Compensation LawÂ  Â§ 131.03 (2004).
The Countyâ€™s argument appears to resemble a species of claim preclusion, though the County does not refer to it as such.Â  Basically, the County argues that because an award by a single commissioner is not a final adjudication unless neither party appeals to the full commission, the change of condition must occur after review of the initial award by the full commission is completed.Â  See Riddle v. Fairforest Finishing Co., 198 S.C. 419, 424, 18 S.E.2d 341, 343 (1942) (holding that because the single commissionerâ€™s award is not a final adjudication, a party may not appeal directly to the circuit court).Â  In other words, under principles of res judicata, Clark is precluded from asserting a change of condition following the full commissionâ€™s order because he could have asserted it before the full commission in the original claim.Â  
The doctrine of res judicata ordinarily acts to preclude relitigation of issues or claims actually litigated or which might have been litigated in the first action.Â  Estridge v. Joslyn Clark Controls, Inc.,Â  325 S.C. 532, 540, 482 S.E.2d 577, 581 (Ct. App. 1997).Â  Nevertheless, a final judgment or award is not res judicata of issues neither asserted nor required to be asserted â€œor which could not properly be asserted.â€Â  101 C.J.S. Workersâ€™ Compensation Â§ 1499 (2000) (emphasis added).
Our supreme court, citing Restatement (Second) of Judgments, section 20(2) (1982), has held that res judicata is not always an ironclad bar to a later claim:

A valid and final personal judgment for the defendant, which rests on the prematurity of the action or on the plaintiffâ€™s failure to satisfy a precondition to suit, does not bar another action by the plaintiff instituted after the claim has matured, or after the precondition has been satisfied, unless a second action is precluded by operation of the substantive law.

Likewise, this court stated in Estridge that a symptom which is â€œpresent and causally connected, but found not to impact upon the claimantâ€™s condition at the time of the original award, may later manifest in full bloom and thereby worsen his or her condition. Such an occurrence is within the reasons for the code section involving a change of condition.â€Â  325 S.C. at 540, 482 S.E.2d at 581.Â Â Â Â Â  
Dr. Greenberg made the determination that Clark needed back surgery to ease his back pain and performed the surgery prior to the full commissionâ€™s order in the initial proceeding.Â  Clark had no way of knowing if the surgery would improve his condition, and, therefore, the degree of change in condition was not yet ripe for review by the full commission.Â  Furthermore, inasmuch as the surgeryâ€™s aim was to lessen Clarkâ€™s degree of disability, the County was not prejudiced by having to wait for the natural and expected improvement of his physical condition following surgery.Â Â Â Â Â  
In Gattis, a claimant sought to introduce evidence not included in the record before the single commissioner.Â  353 S.C. at 105, 576 S.E.2d at 193.Â  The full commission refused to admit the evidence, holding that it would be appropriate for a change of condition proceeding instead. Â Id.Â  The claimant subsequently requested review of the initial award based on change of condition, and the full commission found a change of condition based on the evidence sought to be introduced in the initial proceeding before it.Â  Id. at 106, 576 S.E.2d at 194.Â  The circuit court and this court on appeal affirmed the full commissionâ€™s decision.Â  This court held that because the full commission limited its initial order to a determination of the claimantâ€™s condition prior to the advent of the evidence in question, the evidence was appropriate for the change of condition proceeding.Â  Id. at 109, 576 S.E.2d at 195-96.Â  
Furthermore, it is undisputed that the full commission did not address any change of Clarkâ€™s condition at the time of its decision.Â  The fact that Clark requested in his brief to the full commission that Dr. Greenberg be designated as treating physician, does not lead to the conclusion that the request was actually considered and denied.Â  The full commissionâ€™s order made no ruling on the issue and merely adopted the findings and conclusions of the single commissioner.Â  Because the onset of Clarkâ€™s change of condition began before the full commission made its decision, the County argues that Clark could have moved to admit newly discovered evidence under 25A S.C. Code Ann. Regs. 67-707 (Supp. 2004).Â  However, because Clark did not know the degree, if any, the surgery would relieve his disability, we conclude his claim should not be barred under the unique facts of this case. 
â€œThe determination of whether a claimant experiences a change of condition is a question for the fact finder.â€Â  Gattis, 353 S.C. at 107, 576 S.E.2d at 194.Â  We must therefore affirm if substantial evidence supports the full commissionâ€™s finding.Â  See Solomon v. W.B. Easton, Inc., 307 S.C. 518, 520, 415 S.E.2d 841, 843 (Ct. App. 1992).Â  
Upon his examination of Clark in July 2001, Dr. Greenberg testified that based on MRI results there had been a worsening of his condition since Dr. Epstein saw him in March of 2000.Â  The MRI showed severe progressive narrowing of the spine, a marked worsening of Clarkâ€™s previous condition, leading Dr. Greenberg to recommend urgent surgery.Â  Likewise, Dr. Gero Kragh testified that a comparison of Clarkâ€™s MRIs indicated a change of condition after June of 2000.Â  He opined that the surgery was medically necessary in an effort to lessen Clarkâ€™s disability. Additionally, Clark testified to increased pain in his legs and back after February 2001 and the lessening of that pain after the surgery. He testified also that some of the pain returned several months after the surgery, but not to the extent it persisted before the surgery.Â  Therefore, substantial evidence exists in the record to support the finding that Clark sustained a change of condition subsequent to the prior award.Â  
II. Designation of Dr. Greenberg as Authorized Treating Physician
The County next argues that because Dr. Greenberg was not Clarkâ€™s designated medical provider at the time he recommended and performed the surgery, the full commission erred in ordering it to pay for the treatment. We disagree.Â  
Â After Clarkâ€™s back injury, the County referred him to Dr. Gary T. Fishbach, who referred him to Dr. Franklin M. Epstein.Â  Dr. Epstein opined that Clark was not a suitable candidate for surgery because he was obese and smoked.[1]Â  Dr. Epstein therefore referred Clark to Dr. John Downey for pain management in the fall of 2000.Â  
Clarkâ€™s pain continued, however, and he sought a second opinion.Â  Clark spoke to his wife, who had worked with Dr. Greenberg.Â  Dr. Downey referred Clark to Dr. Greenberg for an evaluation for surgery, noting that the referral was made at Clarkâ€™s attorneyâ€™s request.Â  Dr. Greenberg testified that Clarkâ€™s wife made the referral along with Dr. Downey.Â  Clark testified he asked Dr. Downey for the referral because of the persistent pain.Â  
During that period a conflict arose among the physicians.Â  Drs. Epstein, Downey, and Greenberg were originally in practice together at the Southern Neurologic Institute.Â  The practice split apart in the fall of 2001.Â  Dr. Greenberg left Dr. Epstein and joined Dr. Downey in October of 2001.Â  The breakup resulted in ill will between Dr. Epstein and Dr. Greenberg.Â  In Dr. Greenbergâ€™s affidavit, he testified Clark advised him the treatment he had received from Dr. Epstein was unsatisfactory, and Dr. Epstein refused to provide Dr. Greenberg with Clarkâ€™s records.Â  
After Dr. Greenberg performed the surgery and Clark filed a claim for change of condition, the County demanded another evaluation by Dr. Epstein.Â  When Clark refused to attend the appointment, the County filed a motion to compel his participation.Â  Clark moved to disqualify Dr. Epstein, alleging that Dr. Epsteinâ€™s former relationship and contacts with Dr. Greenberg prevented him from performing a fair and impartial medical examination.Â  Dr. Greenberg also provided an affidavit stating that Dr. Epstein had refused to provide him with records.Â  
After a hearing, the single commissioner granted the Countyâ€™s motion to compel and denied Clarkâ€™s motion to disqualify.Â  The single commissioner found no evidence of bias or prejudice on Dr. Epsteinâ€™s part.Â  
Clark attended the scheduled evaluation with Dr. Epstein in August 2002.Â  Clarkâ€™s wife and a friend, both nurses, accompanied Clark during the evaluation.Â  They observed that Dr. Epstein failed to perform a complete examination.Â  Dr. Epstein reported the surgery performed by Dr. Greenberg was not medically necessary.Â  
In response to Dr. Epsteinâ€™s report, Dr. Gero S. Kragh, a medical consultant, also evaluated Clark.Â  Dr. Kragh confirmed the medical necessity of the surgery, although he said that a pharmacological approach should have been tried first.Â  Dr. Kragh called Dr. Epsteinâ€™s report into question and agreed that Clark had suffered a change of condition.
The single commissioner found the demeanor and testimony of Clark, his wife, and her friend credible and consistent.Â  The single commissioner also drew inferences consistent with the opinions of Dr. Greenberg and Dr. Kragh and considered the conflict with Dr. Epstein and its origin.Â  
The Workerâ€™s Compensation Act provides that the employer retains the right to name the authorized treating physician once a case has been accepted.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-60 (1985).Â  Refusal by the claimant to accept treatment generally bars further compensation.Â  Id.Â  However, the full commission, when it deems it necessary, may override the employerâ€™s choice of providers and order a change in the medical or hospital service provided.Â  Gattis v. Murrells Inlet VFW # Â£10420, 353 S.C. 100, 114, 576 S.E.2d 191, 198 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  The full commission is further empowered to order payment of medical bills in such cases.Â  Id. at 111, 576 S.E.2d 196-97.Â  
Generally, a claimant may obtain compensation only by accepting services from the employerâ€™s choice of providers.Â  However, a claimant is not required to sacrifice much-needed treatment merely to comply with an employerâ€™s choice of physicians.Â  See Risinger v. Knight Textiles, 353 S.C. 69, 73, 577 S.E.2d 222, 224-25 (2002) (holding that â€œthe language of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-60 does not allow an employer to dictate the medical treatment of injured employees.â€).Â  The full commission is empowered to order further medical care when controversies arise between a claimant and the employer.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-60. 
In Ford v. Allied Chemical Corp., 252 S.C. 561, 564, 167 S.E.2d 564, 565 (1969), a claimant who had seriously injured his neck was put under the care of the company doctor.Â  The company doctor referred the claimant to an orthopedic surgeon who was not impressed with the claimantâ€™s symptoms and discharged him.Â  The claimantâ€™s symptoms continued to worsen, and he contacted a family physician who examined the claimant and concluded he was disabled.Â  Id. at 565, 167 S.E.2d at 566.Â  The supreme court upheld the full commissionâ€™s finding that because the claimant had related his condition to the orthopedic surgeon, and received no assistance, the claimant was justified in refusing further care from that physician and in seeking treatment elsewhere.Â  Id. at 567, 167 S.E.2d at 167.Â  
In this case, Dr. Epstein indicated Clark was not a suitable candidate for treatment and referred him for pain management.[2]Â  That treatment was unsuccessful, however.Â  Because Clark related the continuing symptoms to the treating physicians and was unable to obtain relief, he was justified in seeking treatment elsewhere.Â  Although the more appropriate procedure would have been for Clark to seek an order from the full commission before engaging Dr. Greenberg for treatment and surgery, we find that under Ford the full commission was not outside its discretion in ordering the County to pay for the surgery and continuing treatment, once it determined the treatment was medically necessary.Â  See Gattis, 353 S.C. at 111, 576 S.E.2d at 197 (holding that the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act is to be liberally construed and reasonable doubts as to construction are to be resolved in favor of coverage).Â  
We find no merit to the Countyâ€™s argument that the full commission allowed Clark to â€œshop aroundâ€ indefinitely until he found a favorable opinion.Â  In Risinger, the court held this stateâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation statute does not allow an employer to â€œdoctor shopâ€ for a favorable opinion while sacrificing much-needed treatment for the claimant.Â  353 S.C. at 73, 577 S.E.2d at 224.Â  The evidence in the record indicates Clark sought treatment from Greenberg solely for the purpose of obtaining relief from his pain.Â  Furthermore, both Dr. Greenberg and Dr. Kragh testified that Clarkâ€™s condition had worsened after the closing of evidence in the original proceeding.Â  The pain management treatment was insufficient to meet Clarkâ€™s needs.Â  Finally, evidence of bias on the part of Dr. Epstein lends support to the full commissionâ€™s finding that Clark was in need of alternative treatment.Â  We therefore affirm the full commissionâ€™s order in this regard.Â  
III. Total and Permanent Disability
The Countyâ€™s final argument is that the full commission erred in determining Clark was totally and permanently disabled.Â  We disagree.
The full commission found that Clark sustained an impairment of greater than 51% to his back and concluded he was totally and permanently disabled.Â  To qualify for total and permanent disability, a claimant must suffer a 50% or greater loss of use of his back.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-9-30(19) (Supp. 2004).Â  The full commissionâ€™s finding as to the degree of impairment is a question of fact.Â  Lyles v. Quantum Chemical Co. (Emery), 315 S.C. 440, 445, 434 S.E.2d 292, 294-295 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  Accordingly, we must affirm if the full commissionâ€™s findings are supported by substantial evidence.Â  Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 136, 276 S.E.2d 304, 307 (1981).Â  
In the original proceeding, the full commission rated Clarkâ€™s impairment at 30%.Â  Thus, the question in this change of condition proceeding is whether evidence indicates that since that time, Clarkâ€™s impairment has increased to 50%.Â  
Dr. Greenberg testified that Clark is permanently vocationally disabled.Â  He testified that Clarkâ€™s back pain is caused by severe degenerative arthritis with spinal stenosis, which has become incapacitating.Â  Clark will need lifelong medication and follow-up treatment.Â  Dr. Kragh rated Clarkâ€™s impairment in the range of 30% whole body, 40% spinal based on cauda equine syndrome, lateral recess syndrome, S-1 radiculopathy, and possibly myelopathy.Â  
Clarkâ€™s wife testified that she has been the sole financial provider for the family since July of 1999.Â  Clarkâ€™s physical activity level has grown progressively worse since that time.Â  He sleeps only a few hours at a time.Â  He also requires assistance in dressing and using the lavatory.Â  She testified that after the surgery Clark was pain-free for four to six months, but his condition has since deteriorated.Â  
Clark testified his condition is somewhat better now than it was before the surgery.Â  However, he still has pain.Â  He can no longer enjoy hunting, camping, and fishing, his former hobbies.Â  The County has retired him on disability, and he has not worked since March of 2000.Â  Accordingly, we find substantial evidence in the record to support a finding of total and permanent disability.Â  
CONCLUSION
We hold that the full commission correctly concluded that Clark has sustained a change of condition occurring after the prior award, which has rendered him totally and permanently disabled.Â  We further find no error in the full commission ordering the County to pay for the surgery and continuing treatment by Dr. Greenberg.Â  Accordingly, the order of the full commission is hereby 
 AFFIRMED. 
 HEARN, C.J., and BEATTY, J., concur.  

[1] In the original proceeding, the single commissioner noted the wide discrepancy between the conclusions of the experts and ordered an independent evaluation.Â  The parties sparred over which physician would perform the evaluation, and it was finally performed by Dr. James F. Bethea.Â  The original order considered Dr. Betheaâ€™s opinion, as well as that of Dr. Epstein and Dr. James K. Aymond.Â Â Â  
[2] In fact, Dr. Epstein indicated surgery would be a viable course of action if Clark lost weight and stopped smoking. Clark testified he lost some weight and stopped smoking prior to the surgery.

title: Stinecipher v. Ballington
description: This is an appeal from a family court order declining to terminate Thomas Ray Ballington's parental rights to his minor child, Christopher Austin Ballington (Austin). The Stineciphers further argue the family court erred in finding termiation was not in Austin's best interest.  We reverse and remand.
text:
Stinecipher v. Ballington


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Thomas Henry Stinecipher and Hipolita Viego
Stinecipher, Appellants,
v.
Thomas Ray Ballington and Christopher Austin
Ballington, a minor under the age of ten (10) years, Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Lexington County
Â C. David Sawyer, Jr., Family Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  4024
Heard June 15, 2005 â€“ Filed September 12, 2005

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
M. Gwyn DuBose-Schmitt, of Lexington and Thomas M. Neal, of Columbia, for Appellants.
James B. Richardson, Jr., of Columbia, for Respondents.
George W. Branstiter, of Lexington, for Guardian ad Litem.
      
    
  

PER CURIAM: This is an appeal from a family court order declining to terminate Thomas Ray Ballingtonâ€™s parental rights to his minor son, Christopher Austin Ballington (Austin).Â  Austinâ€™s maternal grandparents, the Stineciphers, appeal, arguing the family court erred in failing to find Ballington, who is serving a life sentence for murdering Austinâ€™s mother, wilfully failed to support or wilfully failed to visit Austin.Â  The Stineciphers further argue the family court erred in finding termination was not in Austinâ€™s best interest.Â  We reverse and remand.
FACTS
Austin was born to Ballington and his wife, Edna, in 1995 and was three years old when the Ballingtons separated in June of 1998.Â  After the separation, Edna brought Austin to live with her parents, the Stineciphers. Three months later, Ballington murdered Edna.[1]Â  
After Ballington was arrested for the murder, the Stineciphers took physical custody of Austin and were granted temporary legal custody by an ex parte court order.Â  In October 1998, the trial court issued a temporary order, granting the Stineciphers custody and prohibiting any visitation between Austin and Ballingtonâ€™s extended family.Â Â  
Three months after Ednaâ€™s murder, Ballington wrote his sister from jail and asked her to purchase several Christmas gifts for Austin.Â  According to Mr. Stinecipher, Ballingtonâ€™s brother insisted on personally delivering the gifts to Austin.Â  Such a delivery would have contravened the temporary order, which restrained visitation between Austin and Ballingtonâ€™s extended family, and Mr. Stinecipher refused to accept such a delivery.Â  Ballingtonâ€™s brother testified that Mr. Stinecipher emphatically refused to receive any gifts from
Ballington. 
In June of 1999, Ballington petitioned the family court for visitation of Austin.Â  The family court issued an order appointing a guardian ad litem. Â No further hearing on the matter was ever requested.Â  However, throughout his incarceration, Ballington wrote letters to Austin.Â  Initially, he sent Austinâ€™s letters to the Stineciphers, but when he found out they did not accept delivery of the Christmas presents, Ballington began sending the letters to his sister.Â Â Â  Ballington also wrote separately to his sister, repeatedly asking about establishing visitation with Austin. 
At the termination of parental rights (â€œTPRâ€) hearing, Mr. Stinecipher testified that in the three-and-a-half years he and his wife had custody of Austin, Ballington never sent any money for Austinâ€™s support.Â  In fact, although Ednaâ€™s estate was worth $500,000, those funds were not available for Austinâ€™s benefit because Ballington refused to forfeit his interest in Ednaâ€™s property and life insurance proceeds, and therefore, Ednaâ€™s estate had not yet closed.[2]Â  Ballington admitted he had never sent money to the Stineciphers, but testified that he believed Austinâ€™s support was being paid through rents collected from three properties he and Edna owned jointly.Â  Later in his testimony, however, Ballington admitted that Mr. Stinecipher was â€œnot supposed toâ€ use money from the three rental houses to support Austin.Â  
The family court refused to terminate Ballingtonâ€™s parental rights, finding no ground for termination was proved by clear and convincing evidence.[3]Â  The court further ruled that there was â€œno wayâ€ to find termination was in Austinâ€™s best interest because no expert testimony was offered.Â  Because it refused to terminate Ballingtonâ€™s parental rights, the family court dismissed the Stineciphersâ€™ petition to adopt Austin.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œ[I]n a TPR case, the appellate court has jurisdiction to examine the entire record to determine facts in accordance with its own view of the evidence.â€Â  Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 579-80, 578 S.E.2d 733, 735 (Ct. App. 2003) (citing Richland County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Earles, 330 S.C. 24, 32, 496 S.E.2d 864, 866 (1998)).Â  In this examination and in our determination, the best interest of the child is our paramount consideration.Â  Id. at 579, 578 S.E.2d at 735.Â  In addition, the grounds for TPR must be proved by clear and convincing evidence.Â  Id.Â  Thus, this court may review the record and make its own findings as to whether clear and convincing evidence supports the TPR.Â  Id. (citing S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Parker, 336 S.C. 248, 254, 519 S.E.2d 351, 354 (Ct. App. 1999)).Â  However, this broad scope of review does not require us to disregard the findings of the trial court or to ignore the fact that the court was in a better position to assess the credibility of witnesses.Â  Id. at 580, 578 S.E.2d at 735 (citing Dorchester County Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Miller, 324 S.C. 445, 452, 477 S.E.2d 476, 480 (Ct. App. 1996)).
LAW/ANALYSIS
The Stineciphers argue the family court erred by not finding Ballington wilfully failed to support Austin.Â  We agree.
Parental rights may be terminated if the child has lived outside the home of either parent for six months and, during that time, â€œthe parent has wilfully failed to support the child.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(4) (Supp. 2004).Â  According to section 20-7-1572(4): 

Failure to support means that the parent has failed to make a material contribution to the childâ€™s care.Â  A material contribution consists of either financial contributions according to the parentâ€™s means or contributions of food, clothing, shelter, or other necessities for the care of the child according to the parentâ€™s means.Â  The court may consider all relevant circumstances in determining whether or not the parent has wilfully failed to support the child, including requests for support by the custodian and the ability of the parent to provide support.

Whether the failure to support is wilful is a question of intent to be determined by the facts and circumstances of each case.Â  S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Wilson, 344 S.C. 332, 335, 542 S.E.2d 580, 582 (Ct. App. 2001).Â Â  Wilfulness is conduct that â€œâ€˜evinces a settled purpose to forego parental duties . . . because it manifests a conscious indifference to the rights of the child to receive support and consortium from the parent.â€™â€Â  Id. (quoting S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Broome, 307 S.C. 48, 53, 413 S.E.2d 835, 839 (1992)).Â Â  
In declining to find Ballington had wilfully failed to support Austin, the family court noted that Mr. Stinecipher controlled money from rents in which Ballington had an interest, the Stineciphers never sought support, and Austin had an estate valued at $500,000.Â  However, none of these reasons convince us that Ballington provided for Austin, nor does Ballingtonâ€™s testimony indicate his failure to support Austin was unwilful.Â  
It is true, as the family court noted, that Mr. Stinecipher had â€œcontrolâ€ over the rents collected from the houses Ballington and Edna jointly owned.Â  However, this control stemmed from his being the personal representative of Ednaâ€™s estate and only allowed him to collect the rents and to make repairs to the properties as necessary.Â  Although Ballington testified at one point that he believed he was supporting Austin through the excess rents, he later admitted that Mr. Stinecipher was obligated to account for all the money collected on the houses and could only use the rent money collected to maintain the properties.Â  Thus, Ballingtonâ€™s assertion that he assumed the rent money was being used to support Austin is not credible.
Â  As for the $500,000 in Ednaâ€™s estate, that money was not available for Austinâ€™s benefit because the estate had not yet closed, and it was Ballingtonâ€™s refusal to forfeit his interest in the estate that caused this delay.[4]Â  Moreover, even if the $500,000 were available, that would not obviate Ballingtonâ€™s responsibility to make a material contribution to Austinâ€™s care according to Ballingtonâ€™s means. See S.C. Code Ann. Â§20-7-1572(4) (requiring parents to make a contribution to their childâ€™s care based on the parentsâ€™ means, not the childâ€™s need). Although Ballington maintained he could not support Austin because he generated no income while incarcerated, the record reflects Ballington had significant amounts of money at his disposal.Â Â  While incarcerated, Ballington inherited $30,000, all of which he used to pay his criminal defense attorney.Â  Even after spending this money on himself, he still had $4,400 in his checking account at the time of the TPR hearing, but admitted he never directed his brother, who had power of attorney, to write a check for Austinâ€™s support. [5] Â Cf. S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Wilson, 344 S.C. 332, 543 S.E.2d 580 (Ct. App. 2001) (finding family court should not have terminated parental rights of incarcerated father on ground of his wilful failure to support where prison policies prevented him from earning any income and he had no other source of income); see also S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Phillips, 301 S.C. 308, 310, 391 S.E.2d 584, 585 (Ct. App. 1990) (explaining that incarceration of the parent does not relieve a parent from the duty to support the child).Â  
Finally, although the family court noted that the Stineciphers never sought support, this factor is not determinative.Â  Prior to 1992, parental rights could not be terminated on the ground of failure to support unless the childâ€™s custodian requested support from the parent.Â  However, the legislature amended section 20-7-1572(4) in 1992 so that a custodianâ€™s request was not required, though the lack of a request could be considered along with all other relevant circumstances.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(4) (â€œThe court may consider all relevant circumstances in determining whether or not the parent has wilfully failed to support the child, including requests for support by the custodian and the ability of the parent to provide support.â€); see also S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Cummings, 345 S.C. 288, 296, 547 S.E.2d 506, 510 (Ct. App. 2001) (noting that nothing requires a parent be notified of his duty to support his child before failure to discharge this duty may serve as grounds for termination of parental rights).Â  Thus, Ballington was not relieved of his duty to support Austin merely because the Stineciphers never requested support.
We therefore find clear and convincing evidence that Ballington not only failed to send any money to aid in Austinâ€™s support, but that he actually prevented Austin from deriving the benefits of Ednaâ€™s estate.Â  Were it only a failure to send money to Austin, we might be inclined to defer to the trial courtâ€™s determination that such a failure was not wilful; however, considering Ballingtonâ€™s actions which actually impeded Austin from receiving money from his motherâ€™s estate, we are compelled to find Ballingtonâ€™s failure to provide for Austin was wilful.Â  Finding the Stineciphers proved a ground for termination of parental rights by clear and convincing evidence, we move on to determine whether termination would be in Austinâ€™s best interest.[6]  
The Stineciphers assert that the trial court erred in failing to find TPR and adoption were in Austinâ€™s best interest and in concluding that expert testimony was necessary to make such a finding.Â  We agree.
If the trial court finds a proven statutory ground for TPR, it must also find the best interest of the child would be served by TPR.[7]Â  See Doe v. Baby Boy Roe, 353 S.C. 576, 581, 578 S.E.2d 733, 736 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  If the childâ€™s interests and the parentâ€™s interests conflict, the interests of the child shall prevail.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1578 (Supp. 2004); see also S.C. Depâ€™t of Soc. Servs. v. Vanderhorst, 287 S.C. 554, 561, 340 S.E.2d 149, 153 (1986).Â  While the appointment of a guardian ad litem is required in TPR cases, there is no such requirement for expert testimony.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1570(B) (Supp. 2004).Â  Family court judges often determine whether TPR is in a childâ€™s best interest without the aid of an expert.
We find persuasive evidence in the record indicating that termination of Ballingtonâ€™s rights to Austin would be in Austinâ€™s best interest.Â  Austin was only three-and-a-half years old when Ballington was incarcerated for the murder of Austinâ€™s mother, and Austin has since had no contact with Ballington.Â  Because Ballington is serving a sentence of life without parole,[8] there is no possibility that Austin would ever be able to have a normal father-son relationship with Ballington.Â  Moreover, as numerous witnesses testified, including the guardian, Austin has bonded with the Stineciphers and has thrived in their care. 
CONCLUSION
Based on Ballingtonâ€™s wilful failure to support and because it is in Austinâ€™s best interest to do so, the parental rights of Ballington in and to Austin should be terminated.Â  Accordingly, the order of the trial court is reversed and the petition for adoption is remanded.
 REVERSED and REMANDED.
HEARN, C.J., and BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] This court affirmed Ballingtonâ€™s conviction for murder in State v. Ballington, 346 S.C. 262, 551 S.E.2d 280 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  According to the facts set forth in that opinion, which was part of the family courtâ€™s record, Ballington gave a statement to police confessing to murdering Edna after she told him she was planning to seek full custody of Austin.Â Â Â  Id. at 266-67, 551 S.E.2d at 282-83.Â  Â Â 
[2] Shortly before the TPR hearing, Ballington had finally forfeited his interest in the estate after refusing to do so for three-and-a-half years.Â  
[3] When the Stineciphers initially filed suit against Ballington in October 2000, South Carolinaâ€™s TPR statute did not yet have a ground related to the murder of the childâ€™s other parent.Â  On March 5, 2004, the TPR statute was amended to add the following ground for termination: â€œA parent of the child pleads guilty or nolo contendere to or is convicted of the murder of the childâ€™s other parent.â€Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-7-1572(10) (Supp. 2004).Â Â  However, the Stineciphers do not argue we should apply this statute retroactively, but rather ask us to reverse based only on Ballingtonâ€™s willful failure to support and willful failure to visit.
[4] Ballington did not forfeit his interest in Ednaâ€™s property and insurance until three-and-a-half years after he murdered her.
[5] During oral argument, Ballingtonâ€™s attorney argued that sending a check to the Stineciphers would have been futile because they would not have accepted it.Â  Such a conclusion is purely speculation, especially when letters Ballington sent to Austin via the Stineciphers were never returned to him. Although Mr. Stinecipher admitted he refused to allow Ballingtonâ€™s brother to personally deliver Christmas presents to Austin three months after Ednaâ€™s murder, this alone does not dictate how Mr. Stinecipher would have reacted to receiving a check in the mail.Â  Furthermore, when Ballington testified at the hearing, he never claimed that his failure to send a check was because he believed such an act would be futile.Â  
[6] Because we find Ballington wilfully failed to support Austin, we need not address whether the Stineciphers proved any other ground for termination. 
[7] By contrast, a family court need not reach best interest when no ground for termination exists.Â  Despite this, the family court in this case ruled on best interest even though it found no ground for TPR was proved.
[8] Though Ballington testified that he believed he would one day be freed from prison, the Lexington County Solicitor, Donnie Myers, testified that Ballington was serving a sentence of life without the possibility of parole.

THE STATE OF SOUTH
CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Blind Tiger,
        LLC,        Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        City of Charleston,        Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 4025
Heard June 7, 2005 â€“ Filed September 19, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        James Lee Bell, of Charleston,
        for Appellant.
        Charlton Desaussure, Jr. and
        Timothy A. Domin, both of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.:  In this
civil action, Blind Tiger, L.L.C. argues the circuit court erred in dismissing
its appeal from the decision of the Charleston County Board of Architectural
Review (the Board) as untimely.  We affirm.
FACTS
The Blind Tiger is a pub located at 36-38
Broad Street in the heart of Charlestonâ€™s old and historic district.  City ordinances
require prior approval for alterations to the â€œexterior architectural
appearanceâ€ of buildings located in this area of Charleston.[1]  However, prior to applying for
approval from the Board, the Blind Tiger hired a local artisan to install a
tinted window film and tiger design on the interior front, street-level window
facing Broad Street.  The Charleston Department
of Design, Development, and Preservation became aware that the design and tinted
film had not been approved and asserted the Board of Architectural Review must
approve any such alterations.  Blind Tiger filed a formal application with
the Department of Design, Development, and Preservation for â€œafter-the-factâ€
approval of its window film and tiger design.  The application was
denied.  Blind Tiger appealed to the Board.
On November 12, 2003, the Board
conducted a hearing at which representatives of both Blind Tiger and the city
were present.  At the hearing, Blind Tiger argued the Board lacked
authority to regulate alterations to the interior of windows of a business
located in the old and historic district.  At the conclusion of the hearing
on November 12, 2003, the Board issued an oral ruling upholding the departmentâ€™s
decision and ordering removal of the window film and tiger design within ten
days.  Also, at the time the decision was rendered, a member of the
commission placed an â€œXâ€ in the box of the application next to â€œDenial.â€ 
Blind Tiger did not file an appeal
of the Board decision until February 2, 2004, eighty-two days after the
hearing.  The circuit court dismissed Blind Tigerâ€™s appeal as untimely
under section 6-29-900 of the South Carolina Code (2004).  This appeal
followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In reviewing a decision by a board
of architectural review, the circuit court should act when the board abuses its
discretion by committing errors of law or bases its decision on findings of fact
that are not supported by the evidence.  Gurganious v. City of Beaufort, 317 S.C. 481, 486, 454 S.E.2d 912,
915 (Ct. App. 1995).  Furthermore, our standard of review of a board of
architectural reviewâ€™s decision is the same as that of the trial court.  Fairfield
Ocean Ridge, Inc. v. Town of Edisto Beach, 294 S.C. 475, 479-80, 366 S.E.2d
15, 18 (Ct. App. 1988) (holding the appellate court will not reverse the circuit
courtâ€™s affirmance of the board unless the boardâ€™s findings of fact have no
evidentiary support or the board commits an error of law).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Blind Tiger alleges the circuit
court erred in dismissing its appeal as untimely.  We disagree.
Section 6-29-900 of the South
Carolina Code controls the appeal requirements from a board of architectural
review to the circuit court.  Section 6-29-900 provides, in pertinent part:

  A person who may have a
  substantial interest in any decision of the board of architectural review or
  any officer, or agent of the appropriate governing authority may appeal from
  any decision of the board to the circuit court in and for the county by filing
  with the clerk of court a petition in writing setting forth plainly, fully,
  and distinctly why the decision is contrary to law. The appeal must be filed
  within thirty days after the affected party receives actual notice of
  the decision of the board of architectural review.

S.C. Code Â§ 6-29-900(A) (2004)
(emphasis added).
Blind Tiger contends it complied
with the requirement contained in section 6-29-900 as it appealed within thirty
days of receipt of the Boardâ€™s written notice of the decision.  Blind
Tiger alleged it received written notice of the decision on January 30, 2004,
and filed the appeal to the circuit court on February 2, 2004, which was within
the thirty-day period prescribed in section 6-29-900. 
However, Blind Tigerâ€™s argument
ignores the plain meaning of Section 6-29-900.  That section mandates an
appeal to the circuit court must be made â€œwithin thirty days after the
affected party receives actual notice of the decision.â€ 
Thus, the triggering mechanism for filing an appeal is actual notice of the
adverse decision, not receipt of the written notice.
Actual notice is synonymous with
knowledge.  Strother v. Lexington County Recreation Commâ€™n, 332
S.C. 54, 63 n.6, 504 S.E.2d 117, 122 n.6 (1998).  â€œNotice is regarded as
actual where the person sought to be charged therewith either knows of the
existence of the particular facts in question or is conscious of having the
means of knowing it, even though such means may not be employed by him.â€  Id.
Blind Tiger acknowledged its
representatives were present at the November 12, 2003 hearing of the Board when
the decision was rendered ordering Blind Tiger to remove the film within ten
days.  Therefore, we find Blind Tiger had actual notice of the Boardâ€™s
decision on November 12, 2003, and Blind Tigerâ€™s failure to file an appeal
until February 2, 2004, some 82 days after actual notice under section 6-29-900,
renders its appeal untimely.
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, the order of
the circuit court dismissing Blind Tigerâ€™s appeal as untimely is hereby
AFFIRMED.
BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

[1] See Charleston Zoning Code Â§ 54-232.  Section 54-231 defines â€œexterior
architectural appearanceâ€ as â€œthe type and character of all windows, doors,
light fixtures, signs and appurtenant elements, visible from a street or public
thoroughfare.â€

v.

Consulatants, Inc., a North Carolina Corporation, Cameron & Barkley Company, a Delaware Corporation, Zimmer A.G. a division of MG Technologies AG, a German Corporation, individually and as

of whom
Washington Group International, Inc., an Ohio Corporation, successor to Raytheon Engineers & Constructors, Inc., and Zimmer/Raytheon Consortium are the
Appellants,
and
Wellman, Inc., a Delaware Corporation, and Zimmer A.G., a Division of MG Technologies, a German Corporation, Individually are the

James E. Brogdon, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. Â 4018
Heard May 11, 2005 â€“ File July 25, 2005
Withdrawn, Substituted and Refiled September 21, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Henry P. Wall, Wesley D. Peel, and Bruner, Powell, Robbins, Â all of Columbia, for Appellants.
Alan M. Warshauer, of New York; Elizabeth Van Doren Gray, A. Jackson Barnes and J. Calhoun Watson, all of Columbia; Mark W. Buyck, Jr. and Marian H. Lee, both of Florence; Thomas A. McDonald, Mark D. Howard, David S. Allen and Thomas A. Smith, Â all of Chicago, for Respondents.
      
    
  

HUFF, J.:Â  Washington Group International, Inc., the successor to Raytheon Engineers and Constructors, Inc. (Raytheon/Washington), appeals the trial courtâ€™s denial of its motion to compel arbitration on behalf of itself and the Zimmer/Raytheon Consortium. We affirm in part and reverse in part.Â  
FACTS
Raytheon Engineers and Constructors, Inc. and Zimmer AG entered into a written agreement to form Zimmer/Raytheon Consortium for the purpose of constructing a manufacturing facility for Wellman, Inc.Â  The Consortium agreement provides:Â  â€œZimmer shall act as the CONSORTUIM LEADER for the term of this AGREEMENT.â€Â  In addition, the agreement contains the following arbitration provision: 

  
    
      
        10.9.1     
         Claims between the MEMBERS regarding their respective rights and obligations under this AGREEMENT and/or under the CONTRACT shall be first addressed by the Management Committee.Â  If the Management Committee is unable to unanimously settle such claims within thirty (30) days, its settlement shall be determined according to Articles 10.9.2 through 10.9.4 below.Â  
      
      
        10.9.2    
         Not later than ninety (90) days after the end of said thirty day period either party may appeal its claim to non-binding mediation to the American Arbitration Association to be held in the City of Columbia, South Carolina, under its then effective rules and regulations. 
      
      
        10.9.3  
         Within thirty (30) days of the MEMBERâ€™S failure to reach agreement under such mediation and declaring an impasse or the conclusion of the mediation, either MEMBER may submit the claim to binding arbitration in accordance with the South Carolina Uniform Arbitration Act (S.C. Code Â§ 15-48-10 et seq.) to be held in the City of Columbia, South Carolina. 
      
      
        
        . . . .
      
      
        10.9.4Â  
         If and only if after all said measures have been undertaken by either MEMBER submit the claim to a Court of Competent Jurisdiction and then only to enforce such decision on its own terms or have it voided as arbitrary and capricious.Â  
      
    
  

The agreement also contains an ipso facto provision stating, among other things, if a member of the Consortium becomes insolvent and commences a bankruptcy proceeding, the â€œInsolvent MEMBER (and/or receiver, trustee, liquidator or custodian) shall cease to have any further decision-making authority or vote under this AGREEMENT and the CONSORTIUM shall not require the vote, approval or authority of the Insolvent MEMBER as otherwise may have been required under this AGREEMENT.â€Â  
The Consortium entered into a contract with Wellman for the construction of the facility.Â  This agreement also contained a provision subjecting â€œ[a]ny controversy or claim arising out of or relating to this CONTRACT or any breach thereofâ€ to â€œbinding arbitration in accordance with the South Carolina Uniform Arbitration Act (S.C. Code Â§ 15-48-10 et seq.).â€ 
Subsequent to the construction of the facility, an issue arose about payments due to Raytheon and Zimmer from Wellman and other issues.Â  As Raytheon and Zimmer disagreed as to how to handle these closeout issues, they entered into a settlement agreement to resolve the dispute.Â  The settlement agreement contained the following provision regarding the leadership of the Consortium: 

4. Raytheon as Leader of Remaining Consortium Activities  
  
    
      
        
          (a) 
           The rights and obligations of Raytheon and Zimmer under the Consortium Agreement are deemed completed and discharged in all respects and are of no further force or effect, except
            (i) for the sole and exclusive purpose of serving as the vehicle for Raytheon to assert claims against Wellman and recover damages thereby as contemplated by this Agreement (and to defend any claims which may be asserted by Wellman in connection therewith), and (ii) as otherwise specifically provided herein.Â  
        
        
          (b)   
           Raytheon shall hereafter become the Consortium â€œLeaderâ€ pursuant to Article 4 of the Consortium Agreement for the purposes described in paragraph (a) of this Section, specifically including the unilateral right to conduct negotiations with Wellman, to settle and resolve all claims and disputes with Wellman on behalf of the Consortium, but solely for the benefit of Raytheon, excluding, however, only those claims and disputes excepted from the application of Section 12 herein. 
        
      
    
  

The settlement agreement also contained the following arbitration provision: 

16.Â  Arbitration
Any dispute or controversy between the parties arising out of or relating to this Agreement which cannot be settled amicably shall be resolved by arbitration in the manner provided for in Article 10.9 of the Consortium Agreement, the provisions of which are incorporated herein by reference as if set forth at length herein. 

After Raytheon submitted its claim to Wellman, an electric malfunction occurred in the facility, and Wellman suffered damages in excess of eight million dollars.Â  Subsequently, Raytheon filed for bankruptcy pursuant to chapter 11 of the United States Bankruptcy Code.Â  Washington Group International, Inc. acquired assets of Raytheon, including the division responsible for the Wellman project.Â  Wellman ultimately filed suit against Raytheon/Washington and Zimmer, individually and as Consortium members, for damages associated with the electrical malfunction.Â  Zimmer filed cross-claims against Raytheon/Washington for equitable and contractual indemnity.
Raytheon/Washington filed a motion to stay Wellmanâ€™s claims against it and to compel arbitration based on the arbitration provision in the Consortiumâ€™s agreement with Wellman.Â  Zimmer opposed Raytheon/Washingtonâ€™s motion, asserting that it had the authority to speak for the Consortium and it preferred to resolve the suit in litigation.Â  Raytheon/Washington also filed a motion to stay Zimmerâ€™s cross-claim and to compel arbitration.Â  
After reviewing the memoranda submitted by all the parties, the trial court denied Raytheon/Washingtonâ€™s motions to compel arbitration.Â  The trial court found, pursuant to the ipso facto provision in the Consortium agreement, Raytheon lost its decision making authority regarding Consortium matters due to its insolvency and thus Raytheon did not have the right to demand arbitration in this matter when that action was contrary to the desires of Zimmer.Â  In addition, the court found â€œthat the interests of the parties and the court are best served by resolution of all related claims in one judicial forum.â€Â  Thus it held all of the claims by Wellman should be litigated in court.Â  Raytheon/Washington appeals the trial courtâ€™s order.Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
The determination of whether a claim is subject to arbitration is subject to de novo review.Â 
Vestry & Church Wardens of Church of Holy Cross v. Orkin Exterminating Co.,
356 S.C. 202, 206, 588 S.E.2d 136, 138 (Ct. App. 2003). Â â€œNevertheless, a circuit courtâ€™s factual findings will not be reversed on appeal if there is any evidence reasonably supporting the findings.â€Â  Thornton v. Trident Med. Ctr., L.L.C., 357 S.C. 91, 94, 592 S.E.2d 50, 51 (Ct. App. 2003).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Intertwining doctrine
Raytheon/Washington argues the trial court erred in denying its motions to compel arbitration based on its finding that â€œthe interests of the parties and the courts are best served by resolution of all related claims in one judicial forum.â€Â  We agree.Â  
Wellman urges this court to adopt the intertwining doctrine.Â  The Colorado Supreme Court explained the purpose of this doctrine is to prevent inconsistent determinations by different forums.Â  City & County of Denver v. District Court In & For City & County of Denver, 939 P.2d 1353, 1369 (Colo. 1997).Â  The court elucidated: 


  [The application of this doctrine] involves an analysis of the legal and factual issues relative to each of the factual allegations in the complaint. The court will consider whether the arbitrator would be required to â€œreview the same facts needed to establish the . . . [non-arbitrable claim]â€ . . . .Â  If the factual determinations and legal conclusions are inextricably intertwined, then the court must not sever the action.Â  To hold otherwise would risk inconsistent determinations and could result in the arbitratorâ€™s infringing upon the courtâ€™s duty to decide the [non-arbitrable claim]. . . .


    Id.Â  (quoting Lawrence St. Partners, Ltd. v. Lawrence St. Venturers, 786 P.2d 508, 511 (Colo. Ct. App. 1989)). 
The United States Supreme Court expressly rejected the intertwining doctrine in Dean Witter Reynolds v. Byrd, 470 U.S. 213 (1985).Â  The court held the Federal Arbitration Act (FAA)[1] requires district courts to compel arbitration of pendent arbitrable claims when one of the parties files a motion to compel, even where the result would be the possibly inefficient maintenance of separate proceedings in different forums.Â  Id. at 217.Â  The FAA provides that written agreements to arbitrate controversies arising out of an existing contract â€œshall be valid, irrevocable, and enforceable, save upon such grounds as exist at law or in equity for the revocation of any contract.â€Â  9 U.S.C. Â§ 2 (1999).Â  Considering this provision, the Supreme Court found:

By its terms, the [FAA] leaves no place for the exercise of discretion by a district court, but instead mandates that district courts shall direct the parties to proceed to arbitration on issues as to which an arbitration agreement has been signed.Â  Â§Â§ 3, 4.Â  Thus, insofar as the language of the [FAA] guides our disposition of this case, we would conclude that agreements to arbitrate must be enforced, absent a ground for revocation of the contractual agreement.

Dean Witter Reynolds, 470 U.S. at 218.
Similarly, the Arizona Court of Appeals rejected the intertwining doctrine as being inconsistent with its state arbitration act.Â  Hallmark Indus., L.L.C. v. First Systech Intâ€™l, 52 P.3d 812 (Ariz. Ct. App. 2002).Â  The Arizona Arbitration Act contains identical language to our Arbitration Act, providing:

A written agreement to submit any existing controversy to arbitration or a provision in a written contract to submit to arbitration any controversy thereafter arising between the parties is valid, enforceable and irrevocable, save upon such grounds as exist at law or in equity for the revocation of any contract. 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-48-10(a) (2005); A.R.S. Â§ 12-1501 (West 2003).
The Arizona Court of Appeals found, like the Supreme Court in Dean Witter Reynolds, that â€œthis language does not confer discretion on a trial court to ignore a valid arbitration agreement merely because a case involves related arbitrable and non-arbitrable claims, even if the claims are factually related and difficult to separate.â€Â 
Hallmark, 52 P.3d at 814.Â  
The South Carolina Arbitration Act, like the Arizona Arbitration Act, sets forth the procedure for when a case involves arbitrable and non-arbitrable issues.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-48-20(d) (2005); A.R.S. 12-1502(D) (West 2003).Â  These identical sections provide:

Any action or proceeding involving an issue subject to arbitration shall be stayed if an order for arbitration or an application therefor has been made under this section or, if the issue is severable, the stay may be with respect thereto only.Â  When the application is made in such action or proceeding, the order for arbitration shall include such stay.

Id.Â 
As the Arizona court noted, there is no language in this section authorizing a trial court to refuse to enforce an arbitration agreement.Â  See Hallmark, 52 P.3d at 815.Â  Instead, the trial court must stay the entire action or if the issues are severable, order the non-arbitratable issues to proceed with only the arbitrable issues being stayed.Â  
â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the legislature.â€Â  Hawkins v. Bruno Yacht Sales, Inc., 353 S.C. 31, 39, 577 S.E.2d 202, 207 (2003).Â  The words of a statute â€œmust be given their plain and ordinary meaning without resort to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand its operation.â€Â  Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992).Â  Looking to the language of the Arbitration Act, we find no indication the legislature intended for the courts to be able to ignore an otherwise valid arbitration provision for the sake of judicial economy.Â  The Arbitration Act clearly provides the trial court must enforce an arbitration provision unless grounds â€œexist at law or in equity for the revocation of any contract.â€Â  Thus, we find the intertwining doctrine is inconsistent with the intention of our legislature and decline to adopt it.Â  
Furthermore, we find the intertwining doctrine is in conflict with South Carolinaâ€™s judicial policy of favoring arbitration.Â  See Zabinski v. Bright Acres Assocs., 346 S.C. 580, 596, 553 S.E.2d 110, 118 (2001)(stating South Carolinaâ€™s policy is to favor the arbitration of disputes).Â  We recognize that having litigation and arbitration of intertwined issues may be inefficient and lead to inconsistent results.Â  However as the Arizona Court of Appeals recognized: â€œAny inefficiency or risk of inconsistent results is a consequence of the partiesâ€™ bargaining.â€Â  Hallmark, 52 P.3d at 815.Â  The court must enforce an unambiguous contract according to its terms, regardless of the wisdom or folly or the partiesâ€™ failure to guard their rights carefully.Â  Ellis v. Taylor, 316 S.C. 245, 248, 449 S.E.2d 487, 488 (1994).Â  Furthermore, â€œ[i]f arbitration defenses could be foreclosed simply by adding as a defendant a person not a party to an arbitration agreement, the utility of such agreements would be seriously compromised.â€ Paine, Webber, Jackson, & Curtis, Inc. v. McNeal, 239 S.E.2d 401, 404 (Ga. Ct. App. 1977) (quoting Hilti, Inc. v. Oldach, 392 F.2d 368, 369 n.2 (1st Cir. 1968)).
We conclude a trial court may not refuse to enforce an otherwise valid arbitration provision on the basis of judicial economy.Â  Accordingly, we hold the trial court erred in denying Raytheon/Washingtonâ€™s motion to avoid â€œunnecessarily duplicate proceedings.â€Â  
II.Â  NovationÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Raytheon/Washington also argues the trial court erred in denying its motion to compel arbitration because the settlement agreement acted as a novation of the Consortium agreement, and therefore, the provision in the settlement agreement assigning Raytheon as leader superseded the ipso facto provision contained in the Consortium agreement.Â  Thus, Raytheon/Washington asserts it controlled the Consortium and had the authority to decide whether to enforce the arbitration provision in the Consortiumâ€™s agreement with Wellman.[2]
We first question whether this issue is preserved for our review.Â  Although Raytheon/Washington argued to the trial court that under the revised agreement, Raytheon/Washington was granted leadership in the Consortium and thus had authority to demand arbitration on behalf of the Consortium, it did not specifically argue that the Settlement Agreement constituted a novation of the Consortium agreement.Â  Furthermore, the trial court did not address the effect of the settlement agreement on the leadership of the Consortium, and Raytheon/Washington failed to request a ruling on the issue in a Rule 59, SCRCP, motion.Â  See Wilder Corp. v. Wilke, 330 S.C. 71, 76, 497 S.E.2d 731, 733 (1998) (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€); Summer v. Carpenter, 328 S.C. 36, 43, 492 S.E.2d 55, 58 (1997) (where trial judge did not rule on issue at trial and party did not make a Rule 59, SCRCP, motion for a ruling, issue is not preserved for appellate review).
However, even on the merits, we find no error.Â  â€œA novation is an agreement between all parties concerned for the substitution of a new obligation between the parties with the intent to extinguish the old obligation.Â  The burden of proving novation is on the party asserting it.â€Â 
Wayne Dalton Corp. v. Acme Doors, Inc., 302 S.C. 93, 96, 394 S.E.2d 5, 7 (Ct. App. 1990) (citation omitted).Â  â€œThe circumstances attending the transaction alleged to be a novation must show the intention to substitute a new obligation in place of the existing one.â€ Â Superior Auto. Ins. Co. v. Maners,
261 S.C. 257, 262, 199 S.E.2d 719, 722 (1973).Â  
Based on the language of the settlement agreement and a letter written to Wellman from the members of the Consortium, we find the parties did not intend for the settlement agreement to act as a novation of the Consortium agreement.Â  First, in our review of the settlement agreement, we find its purpose was only to deal with closeout issues with Wellman.Â  The agreement provides:

WHEREAS Zimmer and Raytheon desire to resolve amicably their various disputes and controversies relating to the claims raised by Wellman and to the claims between each other resulting from the execution of the Contract and the Consortium Agreement, with, among other things, Zimmer waiving and providing a full release to Raytheon of any and all claims which Zimmer may have against Raytheon and assigning to Raytheon its claims against Wellman in exchange for Raytheon waiving and providing a full release to Zimmer of any and all claims which Raytheon may have against Zimmer, allÂ  and to the extent as more fully set forth below. 

Also, numerous provisions in the settlement agreement incorporate by reference the terms of the Consortium agreement.Â  One example of this is the arbitration provision, which refers to the Consortium agreement for the procedures a party must follow in seeking to arbitrate a claim.Â  In addition, Zimmer and Raytheonâ€™s intent upon entering into the settlement agreement is evidenced by a letter to Wellman from the Consortium notifying Wellman of the settlement agreement.Â  This letter states, in part: 

This letter is to inform Wellman that from now on Raytheon will serve as Leader of the Consortium on the H-12 Project to address financial closeout-related issues.Â  These closeout issues specifically include the defense of liquidated damages and backcharges assessed against the Consortium by Wellman, the recovery of unpaid Contract balances and the pursuit of affirmative claims by Raytheon against Wellman (hereinafter â€œcloseout issuesâ€).Â  

Therefore, we find the parties intended to modify, but not nullify, the initial Consortium agreement by executing the settlement agreement.Â  
III.Â  Enforceability of ipso facto provision
Raytheon/Washington further argues that even if the settlement agreement was not a novation, the ipso facto provision should not deprive it of its right to compel arbitration.Â  It contends it emerged from bankruptcy prior to the filing of Wellmanâ€™s action; thus, given the policy favoring arbitration, the trial court should have interpreted the ipso facto provision as inapplicable to resolve the matter in favor of arbitration.Â  Second, Raytheon/Washington argues the United States Bankruptcy Code invalidated the ipso facto provision contained in the Consortium agreement.Â  The section upon which Raytheon/Washington relies prohibits the termination or modification of an executory contract, in which the debtor is a party, upon the commencement of a bankruptcy proceeding based on the debtor insolvency.Â  11 U.S.C.A. Â§ 365(e)(1) (West 2004).Â  
Raytheon/Washington did not raise to the trial court any argument concerning the inapplicability the ipso facto provision or the validity of the provision under the bankruptcy code.Â  Additionally, the trial courtâ€™s order denying Raytheon/Washingtonâ€™s motions does not specifically rule on these issues.Â  Therefore, we find these arguments are not preserved for our review.Â  See Wilder Corp., 330 S.C. at 76, 497 S.E.2d at 733 (â€œIt is axiomatic that an issue cannot be raised for the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate review.â€); Summer, 328 S.C. at 43, 492 S.E.2d at 58 (where trial judge did not rule on issue at trial and party did not make a Rule 59, SCRCP, motion for a ruling, issue is not preserved for appellate review).
II.Â  Preemption of Right to Arbitrate 
Finally, Raytheon/Washington argues that given the public policy favoring arbitration, its right to arbitration should not be impaired by it filing for bankruptcy.Â  
Based on our reading of the trial courtâ€™s order, we find this argument misplaced.Â  The trial courtâ€™s order provides in pertinent part: 

This Court finds that under the Consortium Agreement, due to the undisputed insolvency of Raytheon, Raytheon does not have the right to demand arbitration in this matter when that action is contrary to the desires of Zimmer.Â  This result follows from Raytheonâ€™s insolvency and consequential loss of decision making authority regarding Consortium matters. 

Based on the trial courtâ€™s order, it did not determine Raytheon/Washingtonâ€™s bankruptcy preempted its right to arbitration.Â  Rather, the trial court interpreted the provisions of the Consortium agreement and determined pursuant to that agreement, Raytheon/Washington did not have the right to make decisions for the Consortium, including the decision to enforce the arbitration provision under its agreement with Wellman.Â  Accordingly, we find no merit to this argument.Â Â  
CONCLUSION
We find no merit in Raytheon/Washingtonâ€™s argument that the settlement agreement constituted a novation.Â  Furthermore, we find Raytheon/Washingtonâ€™s remaining arguments concerning the applicability and validity of the ipso facto provision are not preserved for our review.Â  We also find Raytheon/Washingtonâ€™s argument the trial courtâ€™s decision was in error because a partyâ€™s right to arbitrate cannot be impaired by filing bankruptcy, is without merit.Â  Accordingly, we find no error in the trial courtâ€™s decision that Zimmer, rather than Raytheon/Washington, has the right to decide whether to arbitrate Wellmanâ€™s claims against the Consortium.Â  However, we find the trial court did err in holding that all claims must be resolved in one forum out of the interest of judicial economy.Â  Thus, we affirm the trial courtâ€™s denial of Raytheon/Washingtonâ€™s motion to compel arbitration only as it concerns Wellmanâ€™s claims against the Zimmer and Raytheon/Washington as members of the Consortium.Â  As to any other claims, the trial courtâ€™s order is reversed.Â  The matter is remanded to the trial court for further proceedings consistent with this opinion.Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.Â Â  
GOOLSBY and STILWELL, JJ., concur.Â  

[1] 9 U.S.C.A. Â§1 et seq. ( 1999).
[2] Raytheon/Washington argues the issue of control of the consortium should be sent to arbitration.Â  In its order, the trial court determined the control issue against Raytheon/Washington.Â  It did not specifically address whether this issue should be sent to arbitration.Â  As Raytheon/Washington did not file a Rule 59, SCRCP, motion asking for the court to address this issue, it is not preserved.Â  SeeÂ  Noisette v. Ismail, 304 S.C. 56, 58, 403 S.E.2d 122, 124 (1991) (where a trial court does not explicitly rule on an argument raised and appellant makes no Rule 59 motion to obtain a ruling, the appellate court may not address the issue).Â
